data:
@TheStalwart @balajis Ethereum is a decentralized computer first, asset second. Its scarcity is not as absolute. 

Band analogy:

If scarcity is the lead singer, changing that means you prolly rename the band (and fork)

If scarcity is a drummer, you can swap it out without changing the band‚Äôs name

data: We did not follow the Ethereum launch, which I helped design, that was extremely successful. So the LTC launched on GDAX was a huge failure IMO. Fred had refused to let Coinbase hold any LTC and due to conflict of interest, I didn't feel it was right for me to argue with him.
label: Negative

data: After taking the summer off in 2016 to work on Litecoin SegWit, I went part time at Coinbase and worked mostly from home. At that time I asked Brian if we can add LTC support given how successful the Ethereum launch was. Brian reluctantly agreed to launch on GDAX only.
label: Positive

data: Although I went along with the plan, it kind of rubbed me the wrong way. Litecoin had a much higher global trade volume at the time and was the #2 coin in marketcap. So although it's fair that Ethereum had more potential, we went out of our way to not launch LTC at the same time.
label: Positive

data: This was also when Ethereum was starting to get big. So I put together a proposal to Brian and Fred Ehrsam (@FEhrsam) to add both LTC and ETH to Coinbase. Basically the reasoning was that it was clear that Coinbase could make a lot of money if it let people trade ETH and LTC.
label: Positive

data:

data: For Ethereum‚Äôs to process a transaction, the transaction must cause a valid state transition (as defined by the Ethereum protocol). If a transaction leads to an invalid state, then the transaction will not be applied and we revert back to the original state https://t.co/GCjSDpYJa7

data: Before the state could be updated to reflect Bob‚Äôs and Alice‚Äôs new account balances on the Ethereum state machine, there are a lot of internal checks that happen (eg verifying that Bob signed the transaction using his private key, verifying that Bob has 5 ETH in his account, etc)
label: Neutral

data:
This requires the state on Ethereum‚Äôs state machine to be updated

But recall that a state machine has rules for which state transitions are allowed.
label: Neutral

data:
For example, let‚Äôs say Bob sends Alice 5 ETH

At a very high level, what we need to do is reduce Bob‚Äôs Ethereum account balance by 5 ETH and increase Alice‚Äôs Ethereum account balance by 5 ETH https://t.co/ZK6K6K5pFh

data:
Just like a regular state machine, the Ethereum state machine can transition from one valid state to the next

The way a state transition happens is through a ‚Äútransaction‚Äù. When a new transaction occurs on Ethereum, it causes the Ethereum state machine to transition https://t.co/pMvoUbduow

data: Had another one of those "this is so cool, I love crypto" moments just now. Sent .0299 TBTC (trustless tokenized bitcoin on Ethereum) through zkSync (layer 2 scaling protocol using zk rollups) to @Melt_Dem which only cost a few cents! https://t.co/RgC0SZWIXg https://t.co/ToTFjoazu8
label: Positive

data: A trustless version of tokenized bitcoin on Ethereum has been one of the areas I've been most excited about and now we minted our first tBTC at @scalarcapital! Each token is backed 1:1 by BTC with no intermediaries. Can't wait to start earning yield on it in DeFi! https://t.co/nrFrVwoKef
label: Positive

data: @kaiynne @VitalikButerin Part of why I joined Ethereum in the first place is the positive, welcoming community so just trying to share my thoughts as I read through a thread like this
label: Positive

data: @VitalikButerin I feel like phrasing a question this way encourages people to pile on and can potentially be discouraging to teams esp those working hard towards building on Ethereum. Maybe we can focus on what are ways to improve existing popular DeFi projects or something along those lines?
label: Positive

data:
If you‚Äôre a VC investing in Fintech, you should absolutely be aware of what‚Äôs happening in decentralized finance (DeFi) on Ethereum. 

I wrote a post explaining DeFi. It‚Äôs not up to date anymore as the space moves quickly but the concepts should be helpful https://t.co/x7CuyRP9CW
label: Positive

data: I‚Äôm excited about the fair launches in Ethereum. We‚Äôll continue to see many more of them become successful. We‚Äôll also continue to see founders raise from VCs but likely the trend being much smaller rounds to get to launch with lower caps per investor which IMO is a good thing!
label: Positive

data: @mattleising I‚Äôm surprised you wrote a book on the story of Ethereum if you think an idea like this is not okay to share publicly. Tons of interesting governance discussions and experiments happening in Ethereum every day :)
label: Positive

data: @harrycanuck It‚Äôs all about memes. Bitcoin has the digital gold meme right now and most traditional investors are far likelier to hold BTC in their portfolio than ETH. Yes this could change in the future but IMO Ethereum community is better off focusing on other use cases
label: Positive

data: @harrycanuck I disagree it‚Äôs zero sum because I believe Ethereum can create a ton of use cases beyond digital gold and ones we have never seen before
label: Positive

data: @jasonklau I‚Äôm still not a fan of the ‚ÄúEthereum is oil‚Äù meme üòÖ
label: Negative

data: @Dalwitter_ @antiprosynth You can just use tokenized BTC on Ethereum if you want to expand the use cases. Not everyone holding BTC wants to do this but the option is there for those who do https://t.co/bwVTE2y1xd
label: Neutral

data: @mikewallace_oz Calling Ethereum people scammers is just arguing in bad faith. Happy to discuss if there are genuine intentions to understand the other side
label: Positive

data: @antiprosynth Yes, I would argue that there will be significant changes to the protocol over time which is a subset of what is discussed e.g. staking, scaling solutions, supply. This is a good thing for Ethereum
label: Positive

data: @antiprosynth I‚Äôm not referring to just the app layer. Ethereum community is far more open to changing significant aspects of the core protocol which always leaves more room for potential issues. IMO this is great for more features and dev community but isn‚Äôt ideal for digital gold
label: Positive

data: @antiprosynth I personally don‚Äôt want my digital gold to be doing all kinds of experiments. Keeping it simple and less prone to attacks/issues is a very good thing and will make traditional investors searching for a hedge feel more comfortable. But Ethereum can capture so many other use cases
label: Positive

data: Still don‚Äôt get the Bitcoin vs Ethereum debates. Bitcoin acts as a better digital gold. There‚Äôs known supply, conservative changes, resonates w/ traditional investors. Ethereum expands on very diff use cases w/ culture of experimentation & not everything has to be figured out now
label: Neutral

data: @jgheller I still don't personally buy the arguments that more usage/demand on Ethereum doesn't accrue to ETH
label: Neutral

data: @zackvoell Ethereum is far in the lead for DeFi so tokenized BTC (both centralized and decentralized) is definitely a major catalyst to me
label: Positive

data: Tokenized BTC seems clearly good for both Bitcoin and Ethereum to me. BTC holders can keep holding as a store of value while BTC can also be used in Ethereum DeFi (trading, borrowing/lending, etc) for users who want it. All opt-in! Ethereum gets more use cases and volume.
label: Positive

data: @antiprosynth @SayEthereum I say Ethereum a lot but in this case, it is a major increase in non-Ethereum or blockchain agnostic teams raising too
label: Positive

data: I think what @Collab_Land_ is doing for community management is really interesting. One feature is a Telegram bot that can connect to your Ethereum wallet to verify token balance before joining a chat group. It could help filter out noise from those without skin in the game
label: Positive

data: I don't normally post about crypto prices but it makes me really happy to see this ETH rally. The Ethereum community went through a lot of criticism but stayed convicted & focused on building. There's still a lot more to go but price does bring in more interest from devs & users.
label: Positive

data: I feel like testnet ETH actually has some value (obviously very small) because of how much development/testing there is in Ethereum. I would pay a few Dai to never have to use a faucet or beg friends to send me some again üòÇ

data: Really interesting Ethereum dapp idea my friend @varunsrin had: p2p gambling where anyone could play the game OR play as the house. Users would bid in an auction proposing odds & the bid with most favorable odds for player gets to be house. One challenge is RNG for large values.

label: Positive

data:
Some interesting design challenges my friend & I ran into when working on our Ethereum smart contract

- gas cost too high for end user
- generating random number (for low values)
- only recent 256 block hashes accessible
- needing an oracle
- miner frontrunning
- txns are public
label: Positive

data:
I love the gamification of using Ethereum dapps!

It's also potential signaling as address with high score = some level of dapp familiarity which can be useful for governance e.g. DAO voting. There could even be separate scores e.g. Compound score for signaling voting delegation https://t.co/dhqj9AyScJ
label: Positive

data:
Nomic‚Äôs bigger vision spans 4 strategic pillars.
1. Solidity (Slang, new dev compiler)
2. EVM tooling (Rethnet, a building block to create debugging tools)
3. Local dev environment (Hardhat, dev env that‚Äôs integrated end-to-end)
4. Ethereum connector library (a revamped web3.js)
label: Positive

data:
@HardhatHQ has already proven to be an invaluable tooling suite for Ethereum devs to deploy, compile, test and debug smart contracts and dApps.

That‚Äôs some serious growth! üöÄ https://t.co/OAgjcDXRlS
